channel.title: NYT > Global Home
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Chinese Solar Company's Operating Unit Declares Bankruptcy
item.description: Suntech Power, which rose to become the world’s largest producer of solar panels, has suffered from quick expansion in manufacturing capacity followed by a drop in prices.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Some Palestinians Wary of Obama Visit
item.description: No American flags or banners to greet President Obama in the West Bank, but some protests have begun; on most posters, Mr. Obama’s face has been painted over or torn off.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Posters in the West Bank city of Ramallah on Tuesday showed the feelings of some Palestinians as President Obama prepared to make a three-day visit to the region beginning on Wednesday.

item.title: South Korea Banks and Broadcasters Hit by Possible Cyberattack
item.description: The police were investigating the possibility of a North Korean cyberattack on Wednesday as the South Korean government braced for more possible disruption.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Afghans Compromise on Special Forces Ban
item.description: After weeks of acrimony, the Afghan government softened a deadline for American forces to leave Wardak Province.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: Obama Arrives in Israel for Two-Day Trip
item.description: President Obama landed on Wednesday to begin a highly symbolic two-day visit to Israel, the first of his presidency, hoping to reassure a wary public of the support of its American ally.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: President Obama with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel at Ben-Gurion International Airport on Wednesday.

item.title: Australian Leader Tries to Save Media Law
item.description: Opposition to oversight proposals has reignited speculation about a leadership challenge to Prime Minister Julia Gillard from within her Labor Party.
item.dc:creator: By MATT SIEGEL

item.title: After Deal Fails, Cyprus Scrambles to Find Funds
item.description: International lenders arrived for talks aimed at resolving the crisis by Thursday, when a bank holiday expires, while the Cypriot finance minister went to Moscow to seek further aid.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Delia Velculescu of the International Monetary Fund, right, and Isabel von Koppen Mertes of the European Central Bank, left, are shown arriving at the presidential palace in Nicosia.

item.title: News Analysis: Iraq War Offers Lessons for Syria and Iran
item.description: On the 10th anniversary of the invasion of Iraq, the lessons hang heavily over the United States as it confronts problems elsewhere in the world.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Viewing Mount Fuji From a Nearby Isle
item.description: Oshima, a short trip from Tokyo, offers hiking, biking and perhaps some of the best views of Japan’s most famous peak.
item.dc:creator: By KELLY WETHERILLE
item.media:credit: Kosuke Okahara for The International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Tourists enjoy the view of Mount Fuji from Oshima.

item.title: Roaming the African, Er, Philippine Plains
item.description: Calauit Safari Park, one of the least-known attractions of the Philippines, is a haven for African wildlife that has operated for close to 40 years.
item.dc:creator: By ALEX FREW McMILLAN
item.media:description: Some of the 35 Grévy’s zebras at Calauit Safari Park in the Philippines.

item.title: South Korean Banks and Broadcasters Report Network Crashes
item.description: The police and South Korean officials were investigating the simultaneous shutdown Wednesday of computer networks at several major broadcasters and banks.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Brooklyn Prosecutor to Seek Freedom of Man Convicted in 1990 Killing of Rabbi
item.description: In the 22 years since a jury convicted David Ranta of murdering Chaskel Werzberger, nearly every piece of evidence in the case has fallen away, and now prosecutors plan to call for his release.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL POWELL and SHARON OTTERMAN
item.media:description: Thousands of mourners attended the funeral for Rabbi Chaskel Werzberger in Brooklyn in 1990.

item.title: Dominican Republic 3, Puerto Rico 0: Dominican Republic Wins World Baseball Classic
item.description: Samuel Deduno and four relievers held Puerto Rico to three hits in the final as the Dominican Republic won all eight of its games in the World Baseball Classic.
item.dc:creator: By TYLER KEPNER
item.media:description: Fernando Rodney, center, who earned his seventh save of the tournament, and teammates celebrating the World Baseball Classic championship.

item.title: Fading Hopes of Unity in Iraq as Sectarian Tensions Rise
item.description: Rafe al-Essawi, until recently Iraq’s finance minister and one of the highest-ranking Sunni politicians, is now on the run from the Shiite-led government.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: At a compound owned by Ahmed Abu Risha in Ramadi, where Rafe al-Essawi sought refuge. Abu Risha, who helped combat Al Qaeda in Iraq, also faces accusation of links to terrrorism.

item.title: Dzilam De Bravo Journal: Quest for Illegal Gain at the Sea Bottom Divides Fishing Communities
item.description: A thriving black market in sea cucumbers — sluglike marine animals considered a delicacy in China — has set off a maritime gold rush up and down the Yucatán Peninsula.
item.dc:creator: By KARLA ZABLUDOVSKY
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fishermen gathered in Dzilam de Bravo, Mexico, recently to discuss a dispute over sea cucumbers.

item.title: Report of Hostage’s Beheading
item.description: Al Qaeda’s North African arm said Tuesday that it had beheaded a French hostage in retaliation for France’s intervention in Mali, Mauritania’s ANI news agency reported.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: French Minister Steps Down in Swiss Bank Investigation
item.description: Budget Minister Jérôme Cahuzac resigned from the French government on Tuesday evening, just after an announcement that he would be investigated on charges of tax fraud and money laundering.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE
item.media:description: Jérôme Cahuzac, facing fraud and other charges, resigned as budget minister on Tuesday.

item.title: Cyprus Bailout Backlash Promises Crucial Test for Germany
item.description: Opposition to an agreement that would penalize ordinary Cypriots could prove to be a decisive test for the German-led push for discipline and austerity.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH and JACK EWING

item.title: Protecting Their Own, Russians Offer an Alternative to the Cypriot Bank Tax
item.description: Gazprom, a company in a tight embrace with the Kremlin, made its own bailout proposal to Cyprus.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Russia’s giant energy company Gazprom, which has often acted at the Kremlin’s behest, has made a bailout offer to Cyprus.

item.title: G.O.P. Opposition to Immigration Law Is Falling Away
item.description: A scramble by leading Republican lawmakers to halt a loss of support among Hispanic voters is providing strong momentum for an immigration overhaul.
item.dc:creator: By ASHLEY PARKER and MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: Senator Rand Paul, in a speech Tuesday, spoke of bringing illegal immigrants “out of the shadows and into becoming and being taxpaying members of society.”

item.title: Pope Francis’ Old Colleagues Recall Pragmatic Streak
item.description: By suggesting in 2010 that the church in Argentina support civil unions for gay couples, Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio revealed himself to be a deal maker willing to compromise.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO and EMILY SCHMALL
item.media:description: Pope Francis arriving at St. Peter’s Square in Vatican City on Tuesday for his installation Mass, which officials said as many as 200,000 people attended.

item.title: In a New Aisle, Energy Drinks Sidestep Some Rules
item.description: The producer of Monster Energy will no longer be required to tell federal regulators about reports potentially linking its products to deaths and injuries.
item.dc:creator: By BARRY MEIER
item.media:credit: Daniel Rosenbaum for The New York Times
item.media:description: Monster Beverage Corporation threatened to sue Deborah Kennedy, a nutritionist, after her newsletter stated that children had died from energy drinks.

item.title: Fading Hopes of Unity in Iraq as Sectarian Tensions Rise
item.description: Rafe al-Essawi, until recently Iraq’s finance minister and highest-ranking Sunni politician, is now on the run from the Shiite-led government.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: At a compound owned by Ahmed Abu Risha in Ramadi, where Rafe al-Essawi sought refuge. Abu Risha, who helped combat Al Qaeda in Iraq, also faces accusation of links to terrrorism.

item.title: Mark Sanford Gets to Runoff in South Carolina Race
item.description: Mark Sanford won enough primary votes to qualify for a runoff between Republicans for a Congressional seat.
item.dc:creator: By KIM SEVERSON

item.title: Iraq War’s 10th Anniversary Is Barely Noted in Washington
item.description: Those on both sides of the debate over the war were largely silent about it a decade after the American invasion.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
